p: DHA and EPA from AOCED were clearly bioavailable as demonstrated by the dose-dependent increases in levels of these fatty acids in plasma of dogs in both generations (Figs 5 and 6). The essentially linear plasma DHA profiles observed in both dams during gestation and lactation and puppies during growth indicate that DHA levels had approached the steady state shortly after GD 28 and increased only incrementally thereafter (Figs 5A and 6A). This supports published human and dog studies which reported that plasma DHA concentrations typically plateau in about a month after the start of DHA supplementation [ 28, 29]. Noteworthy, plasma DHA increases were more dose-dependent in puppies than in dams (Figs 5A and 6A). In contrast, plasma EPA levels increased generally in a dose-dependent manner in both generations (Figs 5B and 6B) and continued to raise with time in dams ( Fig 5B). However, plasma EPA increases over time were more modest in puppies ( Fig 6B).
